node.title: A recent spam attack?
node.bodyText:
It seems like there was an increase in spam rate over the holidays. A quick google search suggests that the same happened in many repositories. I wonder if we can change some of the moderation settings as suggested here https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/27247#discussioncomment-4549334
Some unanswered questions got buried as a consequence, unfortunately. So maybe bump your thread if it has slipped through our eyes...
Forbidding new github users from using Discussions might be an issue for us. Even at the labs some people have been working exclusively with gitlab/others and just got on github for moose

node.title: A question about the "configuration" in the tensor mechanics

node.bodyText:
A general motion with geometric nonlinearity has many configurations which are essentially different ways of observing the same motion. Different choice of configurations leads to different (time discrete) constitutive update of the stress-strain relation. Some may be more convenient than others. You can read "Computational Inelasticity" by Simo and Hughes for more details.
The one implemented in ComputeFiniteStrain is a special one with a corotational intermediate configuration. See the paper by Rashid for details: https://doi.org/10.1002/nme.1620362302
Hi Gary, thanks for your guidance! I will read the literatures you mentioned to learn that.

node.title: Error of restarting a simulation on INL HPC
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am trying to restart a simulation on INL HPC but got an error:
Using g280_out_cp/2770 for recovery.^[[39m
ERROR: Neither one of the following files can be located:
        'g280_out_cp/2770_mesh.cpr/1/header.cpr' nor
        'g280_out_cp/2770_mesh.cpr'
If you are running a parallel job, double check that you've created a split for 1 ranks.
Note: One of paths above may refer to a valid directory on your system, however we are attempting to read a valid header file.

Both of the paths mentioned are valid. I am running parallel, but not sure how to create a split for 1 ranks. In my PBS scheduler file I have #PBS -l select=1:ncpus=24:mpiprocs=12. Any suggestions?

Hello
You booked 24 cpus / 12 mpi procs on the node, but did you use mpirun to run the job?
mpirun -n 12 <executable)> -i ...
The message is saying 1 rank which is odd if you are running in parallel.
What is the header of the simulation reporting for the number of processes?
Guillaume

I have the keyword mpirun, but I did not specify number of processes -n. Now I doubt if it is actually mpi:
module load use.moose PETSc
mpirun /home/wuxuey/projects/moose/modules/phase_field/phase_field-opt -i /scratch/wuxuey/inputs/checkpoint_model4/g280.i --recover g280_out_cp/2770

If this is not parallel, why would I receive the error?
The header of the original simulation (the one I want to recover) says Num Processors is 12.

You should specify -n 12.
What does the header of the new simulation say?
You receive the error because the original split is for 12 procs, but you are trying to read with 1 process

node.title: Anisotropic Diffusion for Cylindrical or Spherical Geometries
node.bodyText: How would one define anisotropic diffusivities that conform to a cylindrical or spherical geometry (see picture)? My initial thought is to create a material object that rotates the coefficient matrix based on element orientation or subdomain boundary orientation; however, I am not sure how to extract such information. I would appreciate some guidance on how to go about this.

Hello
I think you ll want to have the "origin" and the type of the geometry (spherical/cylindrical) as parameters to an anisotropic diffusion coefficient.
From there you ll use the q_point attribute (taken at the local quadrature point index: _q_point[_qp]) to compute the local orientation.
Then when you re computing the qp value of the vector diffusion coefficient, you ll take into account the rotation.
You could have a look at the phase field module and see how they deal with grain orientation / euler angles for an example.
Guillaume

node.title: 'Sample point not found' in VectorPostprocessor
node.bodyText:
I am using PointValueSampler to extract values at the top of the mesh. I am reading points from an XYZ file, that corresponds to a surface, the same one I used for meshing.
 [VectorPostprocessors]
  [pressure_at_top_quaternary]
    type = GolemPointValueSamplerFromFile
    file_name = 'data/Z_quaternary.txt'
    dimension = 3
    contains_complete_history = true
    sort_by = 'z'
    variable = 'pore_pressure'
    outputs = 'p_quaternary_out'
    execute_on = 'FINAL'
[]

This operation ends with an error:
sample point not found: (x,y,z)=(4.45201e+06, 5.72e+06,  314.154)

I think the issue is due to the rounding of coordinates, which forces a sample point that lies on the boundary to end up outside of the mesh. Any idea how to overcome this without utilizing NodalValueSampler or SideValueSampler?

Hello
I suggest you round the coordinates manually inside the mesh. There s no parameters in the PointValueSampler to do that
Nodal and SideValueSampler are good ideas as well
Is the surface flat? You could use a planevaluesampler right behind it
Guillaume

node.title: Coupling FSI module with XFEM - filling crack with a fluid
node.bodyText:
Hello Everyone,
I am Rémi a researcher in Volcanology. I am trying to model the evolution of magmatic intrusions (fluid) in a solid rock. The magma is injected in the solid rock through a crack that should propagate when failure condition of the host-rock are fulfilled. I have been looking around to find a code that can solve propagation of pressurized magma in a continuum domain (the solid rock). It seems that coupling the FSI and XFEM modules in MOOSE could work.
But I would like to ask you directly. Can cracks formed with the XFEM module be filled with a material ? (in my case a non newtonian or newtonian fluid that represents the magma)
best regards ! :)
Rémi

Hi,

Can cracks form with the XFEM module be filled with a material ?

Yes and no. No in the sense that no additional geometry can be created on the fly to represent the fluid. Yes, if you can represent the state of the fluid using some state variables which live on the lower dimension XFEM interface.

Hi,
Thank you for this quick answer.

Yes, if you can represent the state of the fluid using some state variables which live on the lower dimension XFEM interface.

Ok, so I reckon that the fluid won't be properly modelled in the crack, by that I mean that the velocity field and pressure state cannot be solved in the lower dimension XFEM interface... or ?
Rémi

Are you planning to solve for the velocity and pressure field in 3D? Or would a lower dimensional domain inside the crack be OK ?
I ll say that this has not been done before. So it will involve development. I dont see a roadblock in MOOSE for doing that.
The FSI module was not developed for a moving or expanding domain. It can handle small displacements of the nodes at each time step, it does not have the capability to add a new element for example, I feel that there needs to be some treatment in the equation to be able to add elements while conserving at least mass.
yeah, this is definitely doable using the existing infrastructure, it just requires you to do development (knowing some c++ and willing to write code). I know @jiangwen84 has done something similar.

Are you planning to solve for the velocity and pressure field in 3D? Or would a lower dimensional domain inside the crack be OK ?

The plan is to start in 2D (something similar than the attached picture) but if the results are convincing I would like to extend the study to 3D examples.
This is a laccolith model, where the liquid magma (embedded in a solid host-rock) is injected in a pipe from the bottom and circulate in a chamber that inflates as the pressure increases.

My plan is to do something similar than above but to have the pressurized magma propagating through the host rock when failure condition are fulfilled. In this example, the inflation of the magma cavity (the ellipse), induce stress concentration in the host-rock at the tip of the ellipse. In nature, the host-rock would break where stress concentration occurs, creating space for the magma to propagate.

yeah, this is definitely doable using the existing infrastructure, it just requires you to do development (knowing some c++ and willing to write code)

I will try to look at code development and assess if it is doable for me :)
Best regards,
Rémi
To me - this doesn't seem like a case for XFEM... it seems like a continuum model would be better.  Something like PhaseField... or using the LevelSet module.

node.title: Cannot able to open MOOSE website
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Experts,
I am trying to open the MOOSE website on the NREL network and could able to do so.
I talked with NREL IT support and they replied as follows:
"I think you're going to have to find a support contact for MOOSE. We (NREL) are not blocking access to it, but it looks like their site is not responding to connections from NREL at all. It appears to be accessible from elsewhere on the internet, so access from NREL should work too. In case they ask, NREL users would appear to be coming from an IP address on this network: ************"
I am not sure if I can share the IP address here on public platform.
Any suggestions.
Best,
Avtar
@asingh-mit, go ahead and e-mail me at logan.harbour@inl.gov in regards to this
Sent you an email. Thank you very much.

node.title: INSFVMixingLengthReynoldsStress explanation

node.bodyText:
Hello



For an axis, you would expect 'x', 'y', 'z'. The axis_index is simply 0, 1, 2 for those axes respectively.



var_grad * normal is the dot product of two vectors, so the output is an (AD)Real.
We are adding to the normalized strain rate, a number



In this part of the code we are tallying the contribution of the face flux to the Rhie Chow coefficient of the element (ae) and the neighbor (an) of the face.



This part of the code is moving this tallied contribution into the actual coefficient, held by the RC Interpolator user object.
The contribution is weighted by the area of the face (coord() is the RZ radius)



This term is a scalar, an (AD)Real. It s the contribution to the residual of the momentum equation of this term only for one axis.
Hope this helps,
Guillaume

Thank you for the answer. Let me make sure I understand everything:

For the given _axis_index (x, y, or z) specified in the input file, this kernel is called only once for the corresponding _index (0, 1, or 2), right?

In other words,
if _axis_index=x, then by default _index=0
if _axis_index=y, then by default _index=1
if _axis_index=z, then by default _index=2
right?

Let's then assume dim=3, _axis_index=x, _index=0 , then the kernel will return:

norm_strain_rate = grad_u(0) * _normal(0) + grad_v(0) * _normal(1) + grad_w(0) * _normal(2) + grad_u * _normal
which is
norm_strain_rate = du/dx*nx + dv/dx*ny + dw/dx*nz + du/dx*nx + du/dy*ny + du/dz*nz
If _axis_index=y, _index=1:
norm_strain_rate = grad_u(1) * _normal(0) + grad_v(1) * _normal(1) + grad_w(1) * _normal(2) + grad_v * _normal
which is
norm_strain_rate = du/dy*nx + dv/dy*ny + dw/dy*nz + dv/dx*nx + dv/dy*ny + dv/dz*nz
If _axis_index=z, _index=2:
norm_strain_rate = grad_u(2) * _normal(0) + grad_v(2) * _normal(1) + grad_w(2) * _normal(2) + grad_w * _normal
which is
norm_strain_rate = du/dz*nx + dv/dz*ny + dw/dz*nz + dw/dx*nx + dw/dy*ny + dw/dz*nz
right?
2a. We do not take the derivatives of the above because we are in the weak formulation, correct?


Gotcha.


Gotcha.


Gotcha.


Thank you again.

yes. The mapping is as expected, even if the variable names seem unclear right now



This looks correct.
It's (grad_vel + t(grad_vel)) * n but taken only on one axis
2a.
No this is a strong form we re doing finite volume.
However, this is a face/flux kernel, which allows us to drop the derivative.
It's because we are using the divergence theorem to compute this term.
ok, gotcha. Thanks! I may follow up with the items 3 and 4 later.

Can you also explain - how the kernel works for cylindrical coordinates? At which point the code knows that the equations are in the cylindrical coordinates and adjusts the computed Reynolds stresses?

node.title: Finite Elasticity ComputeElasticityTensor is not a registered object
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm trying to run the input file from tutorials (modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/finite_strain_elastic/finite_strain_elastic_new_test.i)
and I get this error. Of course the TENSOR MECHANICS was activated in the Makefile.
*** ERROR ***
A 'ComputeElasticityTensor' is not a registered object.
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.
Can someone please help me.
Thanks

Hello
Is this the makefile from an application you are mentioning? How did you activate it?
Did you rebuild after selecting it?
Does it work as expected with the tensor mechanics module executable?
Guillaume

node.title: Develop constitutive strain-strain equation
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to us the following. constitutive stress-strain relation for my analysis using tensor mechanics:

I have read this object: https://hugary1995.github.io/raccoon/source/materials/IsotropicPowerLawHardeningStressUpdate.html
where only the yield stress is solved for a particular power law, although the hardening_function says it is a function of the plastic strain but is set to call a linearpiecewise functions in most of the examples, is it possible for me to define hardening_function to refer to functions which are expression of plastic_strain, similar to the one above in the plastic domain or as such?
